qas.question: What band did Free lead singer Paul Rodgers help form?
Bad Company's self titled debut album was released in what year?
What nationality was the band Nazareth?
What was Queen's massive 1975 hit single called?
What American act released the song All Right Now?
Which 1970 song by the band Free received no radio airplay in the US?
What 1974 album by Bad Company was an international flop?
What American band released Nazareth in 1971?
What band had the single Bohemian Rhapsody at number one on the US charts for nine weeks?

context: Emerging British acts included <b5_0>Free<b5_0/>, who released their signature song "<b6_0>All Right Now<b6_0/>" (1970), which has received extensive radio airplay in both the UK and US. After the breakup of the band in <a0_0>1973<a0_0/>, vocalist Paul Rodgers joined supergroup <a1_0><b7_0>Bad Company<b7_0/><a1_0/>, whose eponymous first album (<a2_0>1974<a2_0/>) was an international hit. The mixture of hard rock and progressive rock, evident in the works of Deep Purple, was pursued more directly by bands like Uriah Heep and Argent. <a3_0>Scottish<a3_0/> band <b8_0>Nazareth<b8_0/> released their self-titled début album in 1971, producing a blend of hard rock and pop that would culminate in their best selling, Hair of the Dog (1975), which contained the proto-power ballad "Love Hurts". Having enjoyed some national success in the early 1970s, <b9_0>Queen<b9_0/>, after the release of Sheer Heart Attack (1974) and A Night at the Opera (1975), gained international recognition with a sound that used layered vocals and guitars and mixed hard rock with heavy metal, progressive rock, and even opera. The latter featured the single <a4_0>"Bohemian Rhapsody"<a4_0/>, which stayed at number one in the UK charts for nine weeks.
